title: New bike lane in Bueng Nong Bon
text:
New bike lane in Bueng Nong Bon 30 Jul 2015 at 03:28 85 viewed 0 comments NEWSPAPER SECTION: LIFE | WRITER: KARNJANA KARNJANATAWE - + Bangkok Metropolitan Administration will open a bike lane in Bueng Nong Bon, a 1,600 rai public park and reservoir in Prawet district, eastern Bangkok next month. 
Bueng Nong Bon will have a 5km-long bike lane. 
The bike lane will be about 5km long with a separate lane for amateur and professional cyclists, according to Bangkok governor Sukhumbhand Paribatra. 
Located on Chalerm Phrakiat Soi 43, Bueng Nong Bon was originally created to help alleviate flooding. Its 644 rai pond is connected to three reservoirs that have the capacity to hold up to 5 million cubic metres of water. 
Under the initiative of former governor Apirak Kosayodhin, BMA opened the water sports centre at Bueng Nong Bon in 2008 to honour His Majesty the King's 60th anniversary on the throne. It offers facilities not only for water sports like kayaking and windsurfing but also resources for other sports such as basketball and football. 
The bike lane will be the latest facility and BMA will also install CCTV cameras and electric lights along the route. 
In addition, a dog park will soon be opened. Government to invest in new cycling route 
The government plans to invest a massive 1.5 billion baht to build a 184.8km-long bike lane from Thammasat University's Rangsit Campus to Chai Nat. 
The project has been initiated by the Department of Rural Roads (DRR). It will join hands with the Department of Highways, the Transport Ministry and local authorities in provinces the bike lane will be built and that includes Pathum Thani, Ayutthaya, Ang Thong, Sing Buri and Chai Nat. 
The one-year project will kick off next year, according to DRR deputy director-general Prasak Bandhunnark. 
The bike lane will have designated signs only for cyclists and will also have rest areas along the route. 
The project will encourage people to use bikes in their daily lives as well as to promote tourism in the five provinces, he said. Airlines update Lufthansa has launched Premium Economy seats on flights between Bangkok and Frankfurt. 
The airline uses Airbus A340-300 featuring Business, Premium Economy and Economy classes to run a daily non-stop flight between the two cities. 
The Premium Economy seat offers a 38-inch seat pitch and the headrests can be adjusted. The seat also has a bottle holder, a power socket and storage space for personal items. Passengers can check in two bags, each weighing up to 23kg, free of charge. 
The flight departs from Bangkok at 12.10pm and the return leg from Frankfurt is at 5.35pm. Visit www.lufthansa.com for more details. AirAsia Berhad will launch direct flights between Kuala Lumpur and Maldives on Oct 22. 
"Maldives tops the list of 'must-visit' destinations for most people and the requests for flights to Maldives have been extremely overwhelming. We will be the only airline that flies direct to Maldives from Kuala Lumpur," said AirAsia Berhad head of Commercial Department Spencer Lee. 
The new flight will allow travellers from all other regions such as Korea, Japan, China, Hong Kong, Thailand, Australia to connect easily using our Fly-Thru service, he said. 
The airline will fly to Maldives three times a week on Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday. 
The departure time from Kuala Lumpur is 6.55pm and the return leg from Mali at 8.55pm. The flying time will be four hours and 15 minutes. Visit www.airasia.com . Hotels update InterContinental Hotels Group has signed a management agreement with Grand Uniland to open Holiday Inn Express Bangkok Chinatown in 2017. 
The hotel will feature 240 rooms, self-service business centre and laundry room, 24-hour access to a fitness room and free Wi-Fi and breakfast with a grab and go option. The hotel will be located on Chareon Krung Road and will be part of a mixed used project with retail shops, restaurants and bars. 
The new hotel will be the fourth Holiday Inn Express property in Bangkok in addition to Holiday Inn Express Bangkok Siam, Holiday Inn Express Bangkok Sathorn and Holiday Inn Express Bangkok Sukhumvit 11. Visit www.ihg.com/holidayinnexpress . Red Planet Hotels has renamed all of its Tune hotels in Thailand and other countries to "Red Planet". 
The company's hotels will change from charging guests per facility, such as options for using 12- or 24-hour air-conditioning and television, towels, toiletries, breakfast and in-room Wi-Fi, to all inclusive prices like other hotels. 
According to company CEO Tim Hansing, all of its 24 properties in Thailand, Indonesia, the Philippines and Japan already applied the new name and services. 
"We have upgraded Wi-Fi speed in all properties as it is crucial to our guests," he said, adding they had also introduced the Red Planet mobile app which could feed information about relevant local events and points of interest to guests' hand-held devices. It also facilitates room-to-room and front desk calling and a chat line. 
Also introduced is a loyalty programme called Remembered, which has about 1,000 new members joining every month.
